com.explodingbacon.bcnlib.actuators

Class Light

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.explodingbacon.bcnlib.actuators.Light

  • public class Light
extends java.lang.Object
    A utility class for controlling a light connected to the PCM

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      Light(int port)
      Creates a Light on the given port
      Light(SolenoidInterface s)
      Creates a Light with an existing Solenoid object

    • Method Summary

      All Methods Instance Methods Concrete Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      void blink(double sec)
      Makes this Light blink on and off every X amount of seconds.
      void enable()
      Turns on this Light.
      boolean isActive()
      Checks if this light is doing anything.
      void stop()
      Turns off this Light and disables any activities it was doing.

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Constructor Detail

      • Light

        public Light(SolenoidInterface s)
        Creates a Light with an existing Solenoid object
        Parameters:
        s - The port which the light is plugged in.

      • Light

        public Light(int port)
        Creates a Light on the given port
        Parameters:
        port - The port on the PCM where the light is plugged in.

    • Method Detail

      • isActive

        public boolean isActive()
        Checks if this light is doing anything.
        Returns:
        If this light is doing anything.

      • stop

        public void stop()
        Turns off this Light and disables any activities it was doing.

      • enable

        public void enable()
        Turns on this Light.

      • blink

        public void blink(double sec)
        Makes this Light blink on and off every X amount of seconds. On for X amount, off for X amount.
        Parameters:
        sec - How many seconds this Light should spend on and off each.
